headline.main: The Spiritual Life Adds Some Body Toning

docs.abstract: Long Island Journal: Debbie Eisenstadt Mandel, stress reduction specialist and personal trainer, is holding mind-body wellness workshops with nuns, who range in age from 50's to 80's, in Amityville, Water Mill and Bellerose; Jewish and South African communities in Great Neck raise about $75,000 for ambulance for Israel's Magen David Adom with concert by Sydenham Highlands North Choir of Johannesburg, South Africa, under direction of Jeanne Zaidel-Rudolph; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: SLOWLY, serenely, the sisters of the Order of St. Dominic raised their arms to a position called the ''Iron Cross.'' Eyes closed, the nuns held the position for 10 seconds and breathed deeply. Then they rotated their shoulders like doorknobs, lowered their arms and, using their bodies' own resistance, did a series of chest presses. In the center of the room at the Queen of the Rosary Motherhouse in Amityville, Debbie Eisenstadt Mandel, a stress reduction specialist and personal trainer from Lawrence, was teaching nuns to take care of their bodies as well as their spirits.

headline.main: It's a Fat World, After All

docs.abstract: Corpulence is becoming problem in most nations around world, putting new pressure on American multinational food companies; companies exporting to European Union face demands by regulators to sell smaller portions and healthier foods; companies have been exporting salty, sugary foods they are known for, undermining generally healthier eating habits of other nations; maps; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: THE world economy may be slumping, but there is conspicuous growth in at least one area: waistlines. Been to Germany lately? Every third child under age 12 and every fifth teenager there is overweight. How about Greece, land of the much-ballyhooed Mediterranean diet? More than 70 percent of adult men and women in that nation are above their ideal size. The Middle East? About 60 percent of the women in Egypt are overweight.

headline.main: Europe Seeks Firm Limits On Health Claims for Food

docs.abstract: European Commission, in bid to get consumers to eat healthier foods, proposes strict regulations that would make it harder for companies to make health and nutritional claims for their products, especially for foods high in sugar, salt or fat; proposals, portions of which are vigorously opposed by food companies, are strongest regulations ever against misleading or outright false claims; David Byrne, health commissioner for European Union, says restraints are needed; proposals, which need European Parliament's approval, would require that all health claims on food, drinks or food supplements be backed by independent experts; alcoholic beverages could not make health claims under proposal; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: In a bid to get consumers to eat healthier foods, the European Commission today proposed strict regulations that would make it harder for companies to make health and nutritional claims for their products, especially for foods high in sugar, salt or fat. The proposals, portions of which are vigorously opposed by food companies, are the strongest regulations ever against misleading or outright false claims. The announcement comes one week after the United States Food and Drug Administration released guidelines that will make it easier for companies to make nutritional claims that have not been rigorously substantiated.

docs.abstract: Alissa Quart Op-Ed article deplores commercializing of public schools through sponsorships, which schools use as source of revenue; says students are often burdened by overidentification with brands of fast food and clothes and peer pressure to buy unaffordable products (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: ''It's easy, like selling candy to children.'' In the last month, that bromide has taken on a whole new meaning as public school officials have acted to make selling junk food to students a whole lot harder. On July 1, Kraft Foods announced that it would withdraw its advertisements for processed foods from the in-school television station Channel One. A week before, New York City's Education Department banned soda and candy from the vending machines of its public schools. The department's action came on the heels of similar measures by school districts in San Francisco and Los Angeles. The developments are an important step in tackling the epidemic of obesity among our youth. But perhaps just as vitally, they also tap into the issue of commercialism. Not only do schoolchildren put on pounds with chips, candy and soda, they also soak in the brand names that come along with such products. Unfortunately, the issue of commercialism doesn't end with removing candy from vending machines. It only begins with it.
